paper_title: S-scheme heterojunction based on p-type ZnMn2O4 and n-type ZnO with improved photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity

catalyst.source: In the present paper, hierarchical ZnMn 2 O 4 /ZnO nanofibers were prepared as photocatalysts by electrospinning and calcination.
catalyst.context: Inspired by the carbon cycle in nature, it is promising to convert CO 2 into energy-dense hydrocarbon fuels via photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.In the present paper, hierarchical ZnMn 2 O 4 /ZnO nanofibers were prepared as photocatalysts by electrospinning and calcination.They outperformed pristine ZnO nanofibers with about 4-fold increment in CO and CH 4 yields.Except for the advantages coming from the design, such as more exposed active sites and multiple light reflections, other benefits derived from interface charge transfer are also important.To uncover this, density functional theory calculation (DFT), along with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed.Photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved PL spectroscopy revealed that the charge separation efficiency in the composite was significantly elevated.Step-scheme (S-scheme) charge transfer was testified in the composite.This result, for the first time, exemplifies that S-scheme charge-transfer can also be realized in heterojunction based-on p-type ZnMn 2 O 4 and n-type ZnO.It provides a new insight into the design of other Sscheme photocatalysts, which are composed of p-type and n-type semiconductors.

Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) were used to observe the morphologies (Fig. 2).Pristine ZnO nanofibers are very smooth and uniform in size (Fig. 2a).Comparatively, after loading ZnMn 2 O 4 , numerous nanothorns protruded (Fig. 2b).After magnification, Fig. 2c clearly revealed the existence of ZnMn 2 O 4 nanothorns and confirmed that ZnMn 2 O 4 was grown out of the surface of ZnO.The tight contact between them is beneficial for charge transfer and the corresponding construction of internal electric field.The measured lattice spacing d of 0.264 and 0.251 nm in high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images was attributed to (0 0 2) and (1 0 1) facets of ZnO, respectively.Besides, the rest two (0.285 and 0.255 nm) could be classified as (2 0 0) and (2 1 1) facets of ZnMn 2 O 4 , respectively (Fig. 2d).A typical energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy mapping (EDX-mapping) image of the composite (Fig. 2e) agreed well with the XRD results. The optical absorption properties were measured by UV-visible diffuse reflection absorption spectra (UV-vis DRS) (Fig. 3).ZnO nanofibers mainly absorbed UV light below 400 nm; while ZnMn 2 O 4 had strong absorption toward visible light.This is explained by their distinctive E g .On one hand, the light absorption of the composite was better than their unitary counterpart alone.On the other hand, overloading ZnMn 2 O 4 would densify nanothorns and reduced the multiple reflections of light 56.Worth still, excessive ZnMn 2 O 4 would cover the available surface of ZnO.It is similar to the reasonable dense planting.Besides, the excitation light source of ZnMn 2 O 4 /ZnO nanofibers was UVlight 57.It can be concluded that a proper loading of ZnMn 2 O 4 can greatly improve the light utilization rate of composite nanofibers. N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were investigated according to BJH method (Fig. 4a).The isotherms of Z, ZZM5, ZZM30 and ZZM50 could be classified as type IV isotherm with H3 type hysteresis.The relative pore size distribution (PSD) curves (the inset of Fig. 4a) confirmed that small pores around 3.5 nm existed in ZnO nanofibers, which were formed by piling up of ZnO nanoparticles.Instead of nanopores, ZnMn 2 O 4 /ZnO nanofibers possessed more mesopores around 30 nm.This could be ascribed to the tiny slits accumulated by ZnMn 2 O 4 nanothorns.Table 1 compared surface area (S BET ), pore volume (V p ) and average pore size (d p ) of these samples.The greater the loading of ZnMn 2 O 4 , the greater the S BET was.For average pore size, ZZM30 possessed the biggest d p .This could be accredited to the fact that the number of mesopores between ZnO nanoparticles would decrease as the increase of the tiny slits between ZnMn 2 O 4 nanothorns.A proper density of nanothorns was beneficial to achieve the largest d p , which was consistent with the discussion of UV-vis DRS. Two distinct peaks appeared at 1023 (Zn 2p 3/2 ) and 1046 (Zn 2p 1/2 ) eV in the Zn 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 5b), demonstrating that the valence state of Zn was 2 in Z, ZM and ZZM30.The binding energy of Zn 2p in ZZM30 shifted slightly and became lower than that in Z, which proved that the ZnMn 2 O 4 would lose electrons and the ZnO would get electrons after close contact.In Fig. 5c, only one chemical states of Mn (Mn 3 ) could be observed, and it indicated the generation of ZnMn 2 O 4 .In addition, two peaks at 643.4 and 655.4 eV could be differentiated into Mn 3 2p 3/2 and Mn 3 2p 1/2 , respectively 58,59.For O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 5d), two peaks at 530 and 532 eV matched with the crystal lattice (O L ) and the surface chemisorbed oxygen (O C ) in Z, ZM and ZZM30, respectively 60,61.O C and OH are vital active species for ZnO-based photocatalysts 62.The more O C means that more attracted oxygen species or OH.The percentages of the O C in Z, ZZM30 and ZM (in the Supporting Information Table S2) were 51, 53 and 54, respectively.ZM possessed more O C than Z or ZZM30, which coincided with its best CO 2 adsorption performance.The ratios of different elements in ZZM30 were listed in Table S2, deriving from the XPS study.between ZnO and ZnMn 2 O 4 was obviously enhanced.Besides, linear sweep voltammetry curves (LSV) were also performed to evaluate the reduction capability of Z and ZZM30 (Fig. 6b).The over potential required by ZZM30 (385 mA) was much smaller than that of Z (578 mA) to achieve the same current density of 1 mA cm -2 , indicating that charge transport was easier in composite samples.In a word, the enhancement of the charge transport at the two-phase interface could greatly improve the migration rate of photogenerated e CB -and h VB .
